content.content:
## Talk track (fast)

- Envelope upgrades solve **comfort** problems (drafts, hot/cold zones)
- Position as **HVAC load reduction** and **risk reduction** (equipment strain)
- Start with **air sealing** and **targeted window treatments** (films/shading)
- Larger capex (windows/insulation) follows after quick wins and incentive validation

**One-liner:** "We reduce the load your HVAC fights every day‚Äîcomfort improves and bills drop."

## What to verify (fast)

- Dominant load: heating vs cooling vs mixed
- Glazing: U-factor and SHGC drivers by facade
- Air leakage evidence: drafts, door issues, stack effect
- Roof and wall assembly types (continuous vs cavity insulation)
- Thermal bridges at slab edges and metal framing

**Rule:** prioritize air sealing + roof first for many buildings; then target facades/windows with the worst solar or conductive losses.

## What to capture on-site

- Window type: single/double pane, frame type, tint/film present
- Obvious air leaks: doors, penetrations, roof hatches
- Roof condition and insulation evidence (drawings or access points)
- Thermal bridges: exposed slab edges, metal studs, canopy connections
- Comfort signals: drafts, condensation, hot/cold complaints

sections.subtitle: The envelope sets the baseline load

content.content:
# Why Building Envelope Matters

The building envelope (roof, walls, windows, doors, and air barrier) determines:

- **Heat loss** (winter) and **heat gain** (summer)
- Solar gains through glazing
- Infiltration and exfiltration (air leakage)
- Comfort and moisture/condensation risk

Envelope upgrades can reduce HVAC energy and can also reduce required HVAC capacity‚Äîoften enabling smaller equipment at replacement.

sections.title: Windows & Glazing
sections.subtitle: U-factor, SHGC, and practical retrofit paths

content.content:
## Key window metrics

- **U-factor**: conduction through the window (lower = better)
- **SHGC**: solar heat gain (lower reduces cooling)
- **VLT**: visible light transmission (daylight and glare)

### Retrofit options
- Window replacement (highest cost, highest impact)
- **Films** / coatings (target solar gain; faster payback)
- Exterior shading (awnings, fins) or interior shades (less effective for heat)

**Field tip:** document facades (north/south/east/west). West is often the worst for peak cooling.

rows: Less effective at reducing heat gain than exterior shading
content.caption: Window upgrade paths

sections.title: Wall Insulation
sections.subtitle: Cavity vs continuous insulation and moisture considerations

content.content:
## Insulation basics

- **Cavity insulation** improves R-value between studs
- **Continuous insulation** reduces thermal bridging and often performs better than cavity-only

### Moisture/condensation
Envelope work must consider dew point and vapor control. Poor detailing can create condensation and mold risk.

**Rule:** continuous insulation plus a good air barrier often delivers the best real-world performance.

sections.title: Roof Insulation & Cool Roofs
sections.subtitle: Roof is the largest surface area in many buildings

content.content:
## Roof levers

- Add insulation (increase R-value)
- Improve air barrier and seal penetrations
- Use **cool roof** materials (high reflectance) to reduce solar heat gain

Best fit:
- Low-slope roofs with large area
- Hot climates and high cooling loads

**Field tip:** roof penetrations, HVAC curbs, and hatches are common air leakage points.

sections.title: Air Sealing & Infiltration
sections.subtitle: Stopping invisible load and comfort issues

content.content:
## Why air sealing is such a strong lever

Air leakage drives:
- Heating and cooling energy
- Humidity issues (latent load)
- Draft complaints and comfort problems

### Common leakage sites
- Door frames and loading docks
- Roof penetrations and hatches
- Utility penetrations (pipes, conduits)
- Curtain wall interfaces
- Stairwells/elevator shafts (stack effect)

### Verification
- Blower door testing (where feasible)
- Pressure diagnostics and smoke
- Infrared imaging (best with ŒîT)

**Sales translation:** air sealing reduces complaints and improves comfort with quick payback in leaky buildings.

content.content:
## What thermal bridging is

Thermal bridges are conductive paths that bypass insulation:

- Metal studs
- Slab edges and balconies/canopies
- Steel penetrations and attachments

Thermal bridging can:
- Increase heating/cooling loads
- Create cold surfaces ‚Üí condensation risk
- Cause uneven comfort

**Rule:** continuous insulation and good detailing reduce bridging effects dramatically.

sections.title: Shading & Daylighting
sections.subtitle: Reducing peak load without losing daylight

content.content:
## Shading strategies

- Exterior shading: best for reducing heat gain
- Films: reduce SHGC while preserving daylight
- Daylight management: reduce glare while keeping useful light

**Sales translation:** shading and films can reduce peak cooling and improve comfort with less disruption than window replacement.

# Selling Envelope Projects

## Positioning that works

- **Comfort and complaints**: drafts, hot/cold zones, condensation
- **HVAC load reduction**: less run time now and downsizing later
- **Peak reduction**: solar control reduces peak cooling demand

### Discovery questions
- Where are hot/cold complaints? Which facades?
- Any condensation or moisture issues?
- Are doors/hatches hard to close (pressure/stack effect)?
- Are you planning HVAC replacement soon (downsizing opportunity)?

### Objection handling
| Objection | Response |
|---|---|
| "Savings are hard to prove" | "We start with air sealing and targeted measures, and we use before/after comfort + runtime + utility data." |
| "Too disruptive" | "We begin with low-disruption: air sealing, films, roof improvements‚Äîthen phase larger work." |
| "We want HVAC first" | "Envelope reduces load so HVAC can be smaller and cheaper. Doing envelope first protects the HVAC investment." |

questions.question: Which window metric is most directly tied to solar heat gains that drive cooling load?
questions.explanation: SHGC indicates how much solar heat enters through the window; lower SHGC reduces cooling load.

questions.question: Why is air sealing often a strong ROI measure in older buildings?
options: It reduces invisible air leakage that drives loads and complaints
questions.explanation: Air leakage can be a large, hidden driver of heating/cooling energy and comfort complaints.

questions.question: What is a thermal bridge?
options: A conductive path that bypasses insulation
questions.explanation: Thermal bridges are conductive paths (often metal or structural elements) that reduce effective insulation.

questions.question: Why are cool roofs most valuable in many hot climates?
options: They reduce roof solar heat gain and cooling loads
questions.explanation: Cool roofs reflect more sunlight, reducing heat gain and cooling energy.

questions.question: Which measure often has the least disruption compared to full window replacement?
questions.explanation: Films and shading can reduce solar gain with significantly less disruption than replacement.
